item.title: (Non-)Identification in Latent Confounder Models
item.description: Goal The goal of this notebook is to highlight a critical gap between predictive and causal inference. In particular, we consider the problem of identification, which is a central issue in causal inference that does not arise in predictive inference. The causal parameters in a problem are identified if the set of causal parameters that generate the observable data are unique. If the causal parameters are identified, then they can be estimated if the distribution of the observable data can be estimated.
